s.text: He is so excitable that I have to yank him out of the way of an oncoming car when he gets too wrapped up in one of his soliloquies.
This effort has largely succeeded, because Vegas is still the dominant image of American gambling, if not the dominant reality.
This effort has largely succeeded, because Vegas is still the dominant image of American gambling, if not the dominant reality.
This effort has largely succeeded, because Vegas is still the dominant image of American gambling, if not the dominant reality.
It will rebuke state lotteries for their deceptive marketing and will try to force them to post odds and stop targeting the poor.
Wednesday, even commission Chair Kay Coles James, a gambling skeptic, succumbs to the hideous Vegas euphemism: She begins referring to the "gaming industry."
It has also become obvious that the commission has too many pro-gambling members to produce a report that recommends taxes or other real penalties on the industry.
The commission may recommend that gaming taxes be used to underwrite treatment of pathological gamblers and that insurance companies be encouraged to cover gambling addiction.
The industry and Las Vegas' pro-gambling media quaked in anticipation of the onerous regulations and taxes the commission might recommend.
It is tough slogging, but for the first time I sense that this commission--though divided, underfunded, timid, and without any power beyond exhortation--isn't entirely useless.

In the land of gaming, not gambling, everyone is sure he's a winner.

This sets the mood for most of the day: Vegas is great, so you'd better leave it alone!
Tuesday's overpowering show of force by the Nevada gambling aristocracy has had at least one audible effect on the National Gambling Impact Study Commission.

Once upon a time, the casino owners decided that "gambling" was too crude, too avaricious, to describe their fair business.

Later in the day, Nevada's senators and both its congressmen appear to chew out the commission for even thinking that Nevada might have a dark side.

As several readers pointed out to me, "Indian country" is a common phrase in the West and has no derogatory connotations.
